conversation.message: Dear School_C Admissions, I’m Student_E and I’m applying because School_C is my first-choice school. I’m strongly motivated to join your community and would commit to enrolling if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.

Although School_C ranks me (Student_E) relatively low, applying immediately is still optimal because delaying risks losing the only seat to higher-priority students who may apply early. I will send a clear, direct application highlighting fit and commitment to improve my chances despite priority order.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your application and for sharing that School_C is your first choice. After reviewing our current priorities for this admissions cycle and planning for upcoming rounds, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time.

We appreciate your interest in School_C and wish you the very best with your other applications.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_E is 4th on School_C’s true priority list (behind Student_B, Student_A, Student_D). In round 1, only Student_E applied. However, Student_B ranks School_C as their 2nd choice (after School_E) and Student_A ranks School_C last; Student_D ranks School_C last; Student_C ranks School_C 2nd (after School_D). Given the market, School_E will likely take Student_E (its top priority) if Student_E applies there, but Student_E is currently committing to School_C. Still, accepting now would lock our only seat with a lower-priority student and foreclose the chance to match with higher-priority candidates who may approach us in later rounds (especially Student_B or Student_C). Since we can prefer leaving the seat unfilled over a bad match and we have no pressure yet, it is strategically better to reject now and keep capacity for higher-priority applicants.

conversation.message: Hello School_E admissions team—I'm Student_B. School_E is my #1 choice, and I’m very excited about the chance to join your community. I’m ready to commit if accepted and would be honored to take a seat if offered. Thank you for considering my application.

Student_B is our #2, while Student_A is #3 and Student_D is #4, so among current applicants B is best. However, Student_E is our top choice and has not applied; Student_E ranks School_E last, so it’s unlikely they will apply unless rejected everywhere else. In a student-proposing process, waiting risks losing Student_B to another school (Student_B’s next choice is School_C, where School_C ranks Student_B #1, making them very likely to be accepted there if they apply). Therefore, accepting Student_B now maximizes expected outcome and secures a very high-priority match.
